title: How to Caramelize Brussels Sprouts

methods.name: Caramelizing Brussels Sprouts in a Frying Pan

steps.headline: Cut and prepare your brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Place your sprouts in a colander and clean them with cold water. Use a sharp knife to cut away the bottom of each sprout and peel away any hard or dry leaves on the outside. Finally, cut the brussels sprouts in half. The part of the sprouts that you are cutting away is the point where they would attach to the stem. Once removed from the stem, they tend to dry out and become quite bitter. You should only need to cut away around 1/2 centimeter (0.2in) to remove this unsavory part of the sprouts. When stripping away the hard or dry exterior leaves, you only need to remove enough to reveal a tight head of leaves on the inside. As with the base, these exterior leaves are more tough and bitter, so you should remove them to reveal the fresher leaves beneath. Cutting the sprouts in half reveals a larger surface area, giving more room for caramelization and extra flavor to be imparted.

steps.headline: Blanch the sprouts in boiling water for around 3 minutes.
steps.description: Bring a pot of salted water to the boil and add your brussels sprouts. Let them cook for around 3 minutes, just enough to make them tender without removing all of their natural flavors. Pour the sprouts through the colander and submerge them in cold water to stop the cooking process. Blanching any sort of vegetable is a great way to cook them without removing too much of the color and crispness of a fresh vegetable.

steps.headline: Heat butter in a frying pan over a medium heat.
steps.description: While your sprouts cool down in the cold water, preheat a large frying pan over a medium heat. Add a tablespoon (15g) of butter to the frying pan and let it melt and sizzle slightly. For extra flavor, you can use 1 tablespoon of bacon or duck fat instead of the butter. You could also use 1 tablespoon (15ml) of olive oil instead.

steps.headline: Dice 2 shallots and cook them for 4 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Cut your shallots in half and place them on a cutting board. Use a sharp knife to dice the shallots finely into small pieces, discarding the root end and adding the diced shallots into the frying pan. Let the shallots cook for 4 to 5 minutes or until soft. If you don’t have 2 shallots on hand, you can use 1 red onion instead as a substitute. Alternately, if you don’t like onion or shallots, you can leave them out and cook your sprouts by themselves. The shallots add flavor but aren’t an integral part of caramelizing your brussels sprouts. Red onions and shallots will be sweeter and milder than brown or white onions. Anything other

steps.headline: Add the brussels sprouts to the pans and increase the heat to high.
steps.description: Strain your brussels sprouts from the cold water and add them directly to the frying pan. Use a wooden spoon to stir them around slightly so they are coated in the butter and shallot before turning the temperature up to high. Keep your sprouts moving as they cook for around 5 minutes, or until they begin to caramelize. By turning the heat to high, you are essentially stir-frying the brussels sprouts. This will keep them fresh and crisp while adding some color and flavor to them. For extra caramelization, try adding 1 tablespoon (12g) of brown sugar to the pan just before adding the sprouts.

steps.headline: Season your brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Once the sprouts are caramelized and cooked, take them off the heat. Pour over 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of lemon juice and toss the sprouts around to coat them. Add salt and freshly ground pepper to taste. As with the shallots, this isn’t an essential part of caramelizing but will make your caramelized sprouts taste even better. 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of lemon juice is approximately the juice of half a lemon. Serve your caramelized sprouts immediately. Brussels sprouts are best eaten fresh from the stove while they are still hot. Transfer the sprouts to a serving dish and enjoy them as soon as possible. For extra flavor and a hint of extra freshness and color, sprinkle some freshly chopped parsley over the sprouts just before serving.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 425 °F (218 °C) and line a baking tray.
steps.description: Set your oven to around 425 °F (218 °C) on a bake setting to let it begin preheating. Choose a large baking tray and line it with aluminum foil to prevent the sprouts from sticking to the tray. In place of aluminum foil, you can use a silicone baking mat if you have one on hand.

steps.headline: Trim and halve your brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Use cold water to wash your sprouts before cutting away the hard base from each of them. Peel away any hard or dry leaves from the outside of the sprouts to reveal fresher leaves underneath. Cut the brussels sprouts in half and toss them into a large mixing bowl. Cutting open the sprouts reveals the folds of the leaves on the inside. These will caramelize more easily and give your sprouts more flavor.

steps.headline: Add salt, pepper, and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil to the bowl.
steps.description: Pour a few tablespoons of olive oil into the bowl containing the sprouts and toss them until all of them are evenly coated. Sprinkle in some salt and pepper to season the sprouts, tossing again to spread the seasoning. You shouldn’t need to use a lot of salt or pepper to season the sprouts at this point. Start with 3/4 teaspoon (4g) of salt and 1/2 teaspoon (1g) of black pepper as a baseline, adding more or less of each based on your personal preference.

steps.headline: Cook the brussels sprouts for around 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Scatter the brussels sprouts over your lined baking tray and put them in the oven to cook. Check the sprouts every 10 minutes or so and give the tray a slight shake to move them around. Take them out of the oven when they have browned slightly around the edges and look done, which should take around 20 to 30 minutes. The cooking time can vary based on how you like your sprouts. If you leave them in the oven for 10 minutes, they will be cooked, slightly caramelized, but still soft. Leave them for longer to crisp up the edges and intensify the nutty flavor that caramelization brings.

steps.headline: Make a balsamic glaze.
steps.description: In a small bowl, combine 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of balsamic vinegar, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of honey, and the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of oil. Mix thoroughly with a fork to combine and set aside until your sprouts are cooked. The honey in the glaze will help bring out the caramelization of the sprouts, where the vinegar will help cut through that sweetness and balance the dish. The vinegar and honey won’t mix as well with the oil. This is OK, as the oil will help coat the sprouts rather than providing a lot of flavors. Don’t worry if your oil doesn’t completely mix into the rest of the glaze.

steps.headline: Coat your cooked sprouts in the balsamic glaze.
steps.description: Take the sprouts out of the oven and transfer them back into the bowl used to coat them in oil. Drizzle the balsamic glaze over the top, and toss the sprouts around so that they are coated evenly. Serve the caramelized brussels sprouts immediately. Taste your sprouts just before serving to see if they need any more seasoning. A final pinch of salt or pepper might be needed to get the flavors perfect.
